oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Becky Hobbs Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Becky Hobbs (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Becky Hobbs; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Becky Hobbs radio spot for the Music City Album Review (featuring Biff Collie harmony and piano rift) -- (00:08) Hobbs radio spot for the Music City Album Review (featuring Collie harmony and piano rift) -- (00:19) Hobbs radio spot about Collie and the Music City Album Review -- (00:33) Hobbs radio spot with Collie (featuring piano backing) -- (00:42) Hobbs discusses how the title of her album, All Keyed Up, got its name from a shirt -- (01:50) "They Always Look Better When They're Leavin'" is discussed by Hobbs to be a song featuring a past love of Hobbs -- (02:26) They Always Look Better When They're Leavin' (Becky Hobbs) [excerpt] -- (02:34) Hobbs discusses how she attempted to produce harmonies; the harmony part of "They Always Look Better When They're Leavin'" was completed by Larry Gadler -- (03:18) " Mama Was A Working Man" is joked about by Hobbs and Collie and Hobbs recalls Mike Darwin sending her "Mama Was A Working Man" before Don London reworked it -- (04:57) Collie has Hobbs discuss: Bartlesville, Oklahoma, her sister getting a piano, and Hobbs fighting her sister for playing time -- (06:49) Collie and Hobbs discuss how Hobbs played during Sunday School -- (07:20) [Unidentified Piano Tune] (Becky Hobbs) -- (07:38) Collie compliments Hobbs -- (07:46) Hobbs believes "She Broke Her Promise "is her favorite song, and Hobbs tells about how her father made her mother promise him she would remarry -- (09:26) Collie and Hobbs discuss how Hobbs in not a cowgirl, and Hobbs reflects on how Oklahoma inspired " Cowgirl's Heart" -- (10:39) Cowgirls Heart (Becky Hobbs) [excerpt] -- (10:45) Hobbs claims the tune to be an "Indian Type" -- (11:15) Do You Feel The Same Way Too? (Becky Hobbs) [excerpt] -- (11:34) Hobbs describes the tune "Do You Feel The Same Way Too?" to be a 1950s dance tune -- (11:44) Collie and Hobbs discuss what equipment Hobbs brings with her on tour -- (12:29) Collie and Hobbs reflect on the disorganization before introducing "I'm-A-Gonna Get You;" Hobbs tells about the first time Richard Bennett came to visit -- (13:41) I'm-A-Gonna Get You (Becky Hobbs) [excerpt] -- (13:52) Hobbs tells how Bennett's visit was what led to "I'm-A-Gonna Get You" -- (14:06) Collie and Hobbs harmonize to reintroduce the Music City Album Review (featuring piano rift) -- (14:11) Collie and Hobbs reflect on how Hobbs had better success writing song and Hobbs reveals her first unknown album -- (15:00) I'll be Your Audience (Becky Hobbs) [excerpt] -- (15:30) Hobbs tells how her song "I'll be Your Audience" was on Helen Reddy's record -- (16:06) Hobbs discusses Reddy's helpfulness to female artists and how she had a change of record management -- (17:43) Collie inquires and Hobbs tells that she does not have a tattoo -- (18:05) Collie and Hobbs discuss the royalties associated with her songs -- (19:07) "Jones On The Jukebox" is praised by Collie -- (19:35) Jones On The Jukebox (Becky Hobbs) [excerpt] -- (19:43) Hobbs tells how Don Goodman sang " Jones On The Jukebox" -- (20:12) Collie inquires about Hobbs' reaction to Goodman and Hobbs tells what a "hook" is -- (21:49) Collie and Hobbs discuss how Hobbs and Goodman were in discussion when they came up with "Old Flame Burns Blue" -- (22:45) "A Woman Needs" is recalled by Hobbs to be memorable song she wrote in the back of her bus -- (23:15) A Woman Needs (Becky Hobbs) [excerpt] -- (23:26) Hobbs discusses how some of the best tunes might not make sense -- (23:56) Collie and Hobbs discuss the hooks Hobbs has on her album and in "A Woman Needs" -- (24:43) Collie discusses how the "Are There Any More Like You (Where You Came From)" video had been lasting and Collie and Hobbs talk about the power of video -- (26:51) Collie praises Hobbs' charm and both say their goodbye thoughts
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Hobbs, Becky; Collie, Biff;
